awd_titl_txt: NSF-DFG Echem: Design of Nanostructured Noble - Metal Chalcogenide Electrocatalysts for Hydrogen Evolution Reaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Hydrogen will be the most likely fuel of the future despite the technological barriers that still need to be overcome. Layered noble metal (Pd, Pt) chalcogenides with structural formulas ranging from MX2 to MX (M: Pt or Pd, and X: Se or Te) have been proposed as active catalysts for the electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), but the details of the catalytic action are far from being understood. In this project, the investigators will identify the active compositional phases and how nano-structuring (number of layers and step edge density) of these noble metal chalcogenide materials may be used to boost the HER activity. These studies will not only provide fundamental knowledge on the catalytic action of advanced low-dimensional materials, but also define new pathways for the practical design of advanced electrocatalysts, and thus contribute to finding ecological energy solutions for the society. Students working in this project will benefit from a unique combination of different experiences and research backgrounds in a close-knit research network with well-defined responsibilities. They will learn how advances are often made by looking outside of one's respective ‘comfort zone’ and collaborating with researchers in different disciplines that encourages adoption of new viewpoints.

The investigators will use the structural similarities of a wide range of transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) as a materials platform to investigate possible synergetic effects in TMD-phase mixtures (alloys) to enhance HER activity. The planar nature of these materials will aid the characterization of structural and electronic properties of mixed-phase materials and thus facilitate the fundamental understanding of synergetic effects in multi-component materials. A team with complementary expertise and capabilities will conduct these studies. Planar model systems will be synthesized by van der Waals epitaxy, and their atomic structure and electronic properties will be characterized by scanning probe microscopy and photoemission spectroscopy at University of South Florida, USA. The electrochemical properties of these well-defined samples, so far poorly investigated in the electrochemistry community, will be analyzed at the TU Braunschweig. The experimentally determined micro-kinetics results will be rationalized through ab initio simulations to be done at the Helmholtz Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf. The theoretical predictions for alloys and dopants will also guide the experiments and help to identify promising materials combinations. The studies encompass detailed characterization of the materials so that the kinetic parameters and HER activities can be correlated with their physical and chemical properties.

This research is funded under the NSF-DFG Lead Agency Activity in Electrosynthesis and Electrocatalysis (NSF-DFG EChem) opportunity NSF 20-578. The US efforts are supported by co-funding from both NSF-CBET and NSF-CHE divisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project is an interdisciplinary approach for developing principles for the design of van der Waals materials to be used as advanced electrocatalysts in the hydrogen evolution reaction. In addition to the experimental atomic-scale materials synthesis group funded through this NSF grant the project includes a computational materials science group and an electrochemical engineering group in Germany funded through a corresponding grant from the German Research Council. This international, collaborative approach also broadened the research experiences of involved graduate students and post-docs. The US-group worked on the synthesis of planar extended materials, that were characterized with atomic precision by scanning tunneling microscopy and photoemission spectroscopy. This together with input from the computational group enabled a detailed understanding of the materials properties, which then subsequently were characterized for the electrochemical properties in specially designed flow cell reactor in Germany. One main materials system of interest was the Pt-telluride system, which enabled to study three different van der Waals phases. Van der Waals materials are materials consisting of extended molecular sheets that are stacked on top of each other and held together by mainly weak van der Waals forces. Because these interlayer interactions are weak no strong modification of the materials properties depending on the stacking is expected. In this project we succeeded in creating van der Waals materials that can be described by either stacking of PtTe2 layers, PtTe layers or alternating PtTe2 and PtTe layers, with a overall composition of Pt2Te3. Since the latter material is just a combination of PtTe2 and PtTe layer one would expect similar electrochemical activities as the pure compounds. Our studies however indicate that the electrocatalytic properties of Pt2Te3 is distinct from that of PtTe2 and PtTe and thus illustrates that interlayer interactions are not negligible in these van der Waals systems. This points towards a new materials design approach to tune electrochemical properties by synthesizing artificial van der Waals heterostructures.  

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2024
Modified by: Matthias M Batzill

Image

    Appl. Surf. Sci. 644, 158785 (2024)
